Dependency.name: AchievedEffect
Dependency.notes: A tuple that exists between an ActualState  (e.g., observed/measured during testing) of an element that attempts to achieve a DesiredEffect and an Achiever.

Dependency.name: ActivityPerformableUnderCondition
Dependency.notes: The ActualCondition under which an Activity is performed.

Dependency.name: ActsUpon
Dependency.notes: Asserts that something (subject) is acted upon by an OperationalActivity (activity).

Dependency.name: ActualConditionToActualResource
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that a actual resource is an actual situation.

Dependency.name: ActualMeasurementSetAppliesFor
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual measurement applies for an element.

Dependency.name: ActualProjectConsults
Dependency.notes: A relation that expresses that a project consults an OrganizationalResource.

Dependency.name: ActualProjectDependency
Dependency.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a actualproject on a actualproject.

Dependency.name: ActualProjectInforms
Dependency.notes: A relation that expresses that a project informs an OrganizationalResource.

Dependency.name: ActualResourceNeededByActualProjectMilestone
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual resource is needed by actual project milestones.

Dependency.name: ActualResourceToActualProjectMilestone
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual resource is mapped to actual project milestones.

Dependency.name: AffectedActivity
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which resource is affected by a operational activity.

Dependency.name: AffectedFunctions
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which function is affected by a resource.

Dependency.name: AffectedResource
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which operational activity is affected by a resource.

Dependency.name: AlignsWithGoal
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an element is aligned with a goal.

Dependency.name: ArbitraryConnector
Dependency.notes: Represents a visual indication of a connection used in high level operational concept diagrams.

Dependency.name: ArchitecturalReference
Dependency.notes: A tuple that specifies that one architectural description refers to another.

Dependency.name: ArchitecturalSequence
Dependency.notes: A relationship that specifies that one architectural description is the successor of another.

Dependency.name: ArchitectureForProject
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that a architectural description belongs to a actual project.

Dependency.name: BoundaryCondition
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which environment is relevant to an resource exchange.

Dependency.name: CapabilityDependency
Dependency.notes: A tuple that asserts that one Capability is dependent from another.

Dependency.name: CapabilityRoleDependency
Dependency.notes: A tuple that asserts that one CapabilityRole is dependent from another.

Dependency.name: Checks
Dependency.notes: Relation that shows that an acceptance criterion (FitCriterion) is valid for a functional or non-functional requirement.

Dependency.name: Classified
Dependency.notes: Relationship that indicates which classification an element has.

Dependency.name: CompetenceForRole
Dependency.notes: A tuple used to associate an organizational role with a specific set of required competencies.

Dependency.name: CompliesViewpoint
Dependency.notes: Relationship that expresses that a view has been created according to the specifications of a viewpoint.

Dependency.name: ConcernForActualEnterprisePhase
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by an actual enterprise phase.

Dependency.name: ConcernForView
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by view.

Dependency.name: ConcernForViewpoint
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which concerns are covered by viewpoint.

Dependency.name: ConflictsWith
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents a conflict between two requirements.

Dependency.name: ConformsTo
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an UAFElement conforms to a standard.

Dependency.name: ConsumedBy
Dependency.notes: Asserts that a service is consumed by a node. It is not required to know what provides the service.

Dependency.name: DataElementStoredIn
Dependency.notes: Relation says that a data is stored in software.

Dependency.name: DerivedFrom
Dependency.notes: Relation that shows that a functional or non-functional requirement is based on a process, role and task carrier, information element or other element.

Dependency.name: DescribedBy
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description describes an architecture.

Dependency.name: DesiredEffect
Dependency.notes: A tuple relating the Desirer (a Capability or OrganizationalResource) to an ActualState.

Dependency.name: EnvironmentalCondition
Dependency.notes: Relationship that indicates under which environment an exhibits-relationship takes place.

Dependency.name: EnvironmentalContext
Dependency.notes: Relationship that indicates under which condition an measurement counts.

Dependency.name: Expresses
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following architectures.

Dependency.name: Forecast
Dependency.notes: A tuple that specifies a transition from one Asset, Standard, Competence to another future one. It is related to an ActualEnterprisePhase to give it a temporal context.

Dependency.name: ForecastPeriod
Dependency.notes: Planning phase for which the forecast is valid.

Dependency.name: FormStoredIn
Dependency.notes: Relation states that a digital form is stored in software.

Dependency.name: FunctionSubject
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that a function uses certain resources.

Dependency.name: GoalForActualEnterprisePhase
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual enterprisephase implements an enterprisegoal.

Dependency.name: HostedOn
Dependency.notes: Relation states that hardware (virtualized) or software is hosted on a virtualized platform or physical hardware.

Dependency.name: ImplementsProtocol
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which protocol implements an architectural element.

Dependency.name: IsAccountableFor
Dependency.notes: A relation that expresses that an OrganizationalResource is responsible for a resource, service or project in the context of an approval.

Dependency.name: IsDuplicateOf
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents that two requirements convey the same content.

Dependency.name: IsEquivalentToStandardElement
Dependency.notes: Relationship that indicates that a model element corresponds to a catalog element.

Dependency.name: IsResponsibleFor
Dependency.notes: A relation that expresses that an OrganizationalResource is responsible for a resource, service or project.

Dependency.name: JustifiedBy
Dependency.notes: Relation states that an Constraint is derived from a reference (Reference, DocumentReference, SMEReference).

Dependency.name: LocationType
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which location is assigned to a location holder.

Dependency.name: MilestoneDependency
Dependency.notes: A tuple between two ActualProjectMilestones that denotes one ActualProjectMilestone follows from another.

Dependency.name: NeedsModificationOf
Dependency.notes: Relation stats that a project makes adjustments to a resource.

Dependency.name: NeedsResource
Dependency.notes: Relation stats that a project needs a resource.

Dependency.name: NeedsService
Dependency.notes: A relation that expresses that a project needs a service

Dependency.name: OperationalArchitectureOfEnterprisePhase
Dependency.notes: Relationship that says that in a actual enterprisephase an operational architecture is valid.

Dependency.name: OriginatesFrom
Dependency.notes: Relation that derives an element in the architectural model from a reference (Reference, DocumentReference, SMEReference).

Dependency.name: OwnedMilestone
Dependency.notes: Relationship that expresses that actual project has a actual milestone.

Dependency.name: OwnsActualMeasurementSet
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual measurement set an element owns.

Dependency.name: OwnsMeasurement
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which measurement or measurement type an element owns.

Dependency.name: PhysicalArchitectureOfEnterprisePhase
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual enterprise phase has resource architectures.

Dependency.name: PhysicalLocation
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that a location holder operates in an actual location.

Dependency.name: ProjectMilestoneToProjectTheme
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which project theme is handled by which project milestone.

Dependency.name: ProjectProvidesFunction
Dependency.notes: Relation stats that a project realizes a function.

Dependency.name: ProjectSequence
Dependency.notes: A tuple between two ActualProjects that denotes one ActualProject cannot start before the previous ActualProject is finished.

Dependency.name: ProjectSupportActivity
Dependency.notes: Relation stats that a project supports an activity.

Dependency.name: Provides
Dependency.notes: Asserts that a operational agent provides a service.

Dependency.name: ProvidesCompetence
Dependency.notes: A tuple that asserts that an ActualOrganizationalResource provides a specific set of Competencies.

Dependency.name: ProvidesServiceFunction
Dependency.notes: Relationship that expresses that a service function is provided by an interface.

Dependency.name: RatifiedStandards
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual organization releases a standard.

Dependency.name: RealizedDesiredEffect
Dependency.notes: Relationship that expresses which connector DesiredEffect the connector AchievedEffect realizes.

Dependency.name: RealizingAchievedEffect
Dependency.notes: Relationship that expresses which connector AchievedEffect realizes the connector DesiredEffect.

Dependency.name: RefersTo
Dependency.notes: Relationship that assigns a finding to a recommendation.

Dependency.name: Refines
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents a refinement of a requirement by another requirement.

Dependency.name: Replaces
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents a replacement of a requirement with another requirement.

Dependency.name: ReplaceStandardElement
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents a replacement of a standard element with another standard element

Dependency.name: RequiredEnvironment
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that a location holder operates under specific environmental conditions.

Dependency.name: RequiredResource
Dependency.notes: Relationship that indicates which resources a project milestone requires

Dependency.name: Requires
Dependency.notes: Relation that represents that a requirement assumes another requirement.

Dependency.name: ResourceDependency
Dependency.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a resource on a resource.

Dependency.name: ResourceToServiceDependency
Dependency.notes: Relation states that a resource is dependent on a service.

Dependency.name: Responsible
Dependency.notes: Relation states that a project is responsible for a service or a material resource.

Dependency.name: ResultsFrom
Dependency.notes: Relationship expresses that an element of architecture is the reason for a finding.

Dependency.name: SameAs
Dependency.notes: A tuple that asserts that two elements refer to the same real-world thing.

Dependency.name: Satisfy
Dependency.notes: This relation states that an constraint affects an element.

Dependency.name: ServiceClassification
Dependency.notes: Relation is used to show that two services have a relationship in the sense of a taxonomy.

Dependency.name: ServiceDependency
Dependency.notes: Relationship that is a dependency of a service on a service, operational node or resource.

Dependency.name: StakeholderConcern
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which concern a stakeholder has.

Dependency.name: StatementTask
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual enterprise phase fulfills a actual enduring task.

Dependency.name: StemsFrom
Dependency.notes: Relationship that states that one requirement stems from another.

Dependency.name: StoredIn
Dependency.notes: Relation states that a digital form or data is stored in software.

Dependency.name: SuccessorOf
Dependency.notes: A relationship between two elements that indicates that one element is the successor of the other.

Dependency.name: ToBeRealizedBy
Dependency.notes: Relation states that a functional or non-functional requirement should be realized through this element.

Dependency.name: VersionReleased
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual project milestone releases an versioned element.

Dependency.name: VersionSuccession
Dependency.notes: A tuple between two  VersionOfConfigurations that denotes that one VersionOfConfiguration follows from another.

Dependency.name: VersionWithdrawn
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an actual project milestone withdraws an versioned element.

Dependency.name: ViewpointsInArchitecturalDescription
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following viewpoints.

Dependency.name: ViewpointToStakeholder
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which stakeholder needs viewpoint.

Dependency.name: ViewsInArchitecturalDescription
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses that an architectural description includes the following views.

Dependency.name: VisionForActualEnterprisePhase
Dependency.notes: A relationship that expresses which actual enterprisephase implements an enterprisevision.

Object.name: Achiever
Object.notes: An ActualResource, ActualProject or ActualEnterprisePhase that can deliver a DesiredEffect.

Object.name: ActualCondition
Object.notes: An individual describing an actual situation with respect to circumstances under which an OperationalActivity, Function or ServiceFunction can be performed.

Object.name: ActualEnduringTask
Object.notes: An actual undertaking recognized by an enterprise as being essential to achieving its goals - i.e. a strategic specification of what the enterprise does.

Object.name: ActualEnterprisePhase
Object.notes: The ActualState that describes the phase of an Enterprise endeavor.

Object.name: ActualEnvironment
Object.notes: The ActualState that describes the circumstances of an Environment.

Object.name: ActualLocation
Object.notes: The ActualState that describes a physical location, for example using text to provide an address, Geo-coordinates, etc.

Object.name: ActualMeasurementSet
Object.notes: A set of ActualMeasurements.

Object.name: ActualOrganization
Object.notes: An actual formal or informal organizational unit, e.g. "Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency", "UAF team Alpha".

Object.name: ActualOrganizationalResource
Object.notes: Abstract element for an ActualOrganization, ActualPerson or ActualPost.

Object.name: ActualPerson
Object.notes: An individual human being.

Object.name: ActualPost
Object.notes: An actual, specific post, an instance of a Post "type" - e.g., "President of the United States of America." where the Post would be president.

Object.name: ActualProject
Object.notes: A time-limited endeavor to provide a specific set of ActualResource that meet specific Capability needs.

Object.name: ActualProjectMilestone
Object.notes: An event with a start date in a ActualProject from which progress is measured.

Object.name: ActualPropertySet
Object.notes: A set or collection of Actual properties.

Object.name: ActualResource
Object.notes: Role in an Organisation, where the role carries the authority to undertake a function - through the ActualOrganizationalResource given the role has the responsibility.

Object.name: ActualResponsibleResource
Object.notes: An abstract type grouping responsible OrganizationalResources.

Object.name: ActualService
Object.notes: An individual ServiceSpecification.

Object.name: ActualState
Object.notes: Abstract element that applies temporal extent to a set of elements realized as Instance Specifications.

Object.name: FieldedCapability
Object.notes: An individual, fully-realized capability.

Object.name: ProvidedServiceLevel
Object.notes: A sub type of ActualService that details a specific service level delivered by the provider.

Object.name: RequiredServiceLevel
Object.notes: A sub type of ActualService that details a specific service level required of the provider.

Realisation.name: ActivitySupportsService
Realisation.notes: Relation states that a process is necessary for the implementation of a service.

Realisation.name: Evaluates
Realisation.notes: This relation states that an evaluation criterion (FulfilmentCriterion) can be assigned to a specific acceptance criterion (FitCriterion).

Realisation.name: RealiseRequirement
Realisation.notes: Relation states that a functional or non-functional requirement is realized through this element.

Realisation.name: RealizesRecommendation
Realisation.notes: Relation states that a Recommendation is realized through this element.

Slot.name: ActualMeasurement
Slot.notes: An actual value that is applied to a Measurement.

Slot.name: ActualOrganizationRole
Slot.notes: An ActualOrganizationalResource that is applied to a ResourceRole.

Slot.name: ActualProjectMilestoneRole
Slot.notes: An ActualProjectMilestone that is applied to a ProjectMilestoneRole.

Slot.name: ActualServiceSpecificationRole
Slot.notes: An instance of a ServiceSpecification in context of a ServiceSpecification.

Slot.name: ProjectStatus
Slot.notes: The status (i.e. level of progress) of a ProjectTheme for an ActualProject at the time of the ActualProjectMilestone.

InformationFlow.name: ActualResourceRelationship
InformationFlow.notes: An actual resource flow existing between ActualResources (i.e. flow of data, people, materiel, or energy).

InformationFlow.name: Command
InformationFlow.notes: A type of ResourceExchange that asserts that one OrganizationalResource commands another.

InformationFlow.name: Control
InformationFlow.notes: A type of ResourceExchange that asserts that one PhysicalResource controls another PhysicalResource (i.e.  the driver of a vehicle controlling the vehicle speed or direction).

InformationFlow.name: OperationalExchange
InformationFlow.notes: Asserts that a flow can exist between OperationalPerformers (i.e. flows of information, people, materiel, or energy).

InformationFlow.name: ResourceExchange
InformationFlow.notes: Asserts that a flow can exist between ResourcePerformers (i.e. flows of data, people, material, or energy).

Note.name: Alias
Note.notes: A metamodel Artifact used to define an alternative name for an element.

Note.name: ArchitectureMetadata
Note.notes: Information associated with an ArchitecturalDescription, that supplements the standard set of tags used to summarize the Architecture. It states things like what methodology was used, notation, etc.

Note.name: Definition
Note.notes: A comment containing a description of an element in the architecture.

Note.name: Information
Note.notes: A comment that describes the state of an item of interest in any medium or form -- and is communicated or received.

Note.name: Metadata
Note.notes: A comment that can be applied to any element in the architecture. The attributes associated with this element details the relationship between the element and its related dublinCoreElement, metaDataScheme, category and name. This allows the element to be referenced using the Semantic Web.

Package.name: ArchitecturalDescription
Package.notes: An Architecture Description is a work product used to express the Architecture of some System Of Interest. It provides executive-level summary information about the architecture description in a consistent form to allow quick reference and comparison between architecture descriptions -- It includes assumptions, constraints, and limitations that may affect high-level decisions relating to an architecture-based work program.

Package.name: DataModel
Package.notes: A structural specification of data types, showing relationships between them that is devoid of implementation detail. The type of data captured in the DataModel is described using the enumaration DataModelKind (Conceptual,Logical and Physical).

Class.name: Architecture
Class.notes: An abstract type that represents a generic architecture. Subtypes are OperationalArchitecture and ResourceArchitecture.

Class.name: Asset
Class.notes: Asset as applied to Security views, an abstract type that indicates the types of elements that can be considered as a subject for security analysis.

Class.name: Capability
Class.notes: A high level specification of the enterprise's ability to execute a specified course of action.

Class.name: CapabilityConfiguration
Class.notes: A composite structure representing the physical and human resources (and their interactions) in an enterprise, assembled to meet a capability).

Class.name: Classification
Class.notes: Classification according to STANAG 1059.

Class.name: Competence
Class.notes: A specific set of abilities defined by knowledge, skills and aptitude.

Class.name: Concern
Class.notes: Interest in an EnterprisePhase (EnterprisePhase is synonym for System in ISO 42010) relevant to one or more of its stakeholders.

Class.name: Condition
Class.notes: A type that defines the Location, Environment and/or GeoPoliticalExtent.

Class.name: DataElement
Class.notes: A formalized representation of data that is managed by or exchanged between resources.

Class.name: DocumentReference
Class.notes: The element describes a regulation, instruction or a general document.

Class.name: EnduringTask
Class.notes: A type of template behavior recognized by an enterprise as being essential to achieving its goals - i.e. a template for a strategic specification of what the enterprise does.

Class.name: Energy
Class.notes: A representation of any kind of energy.

Class.name: EnterpriseGoal
Class.notes: A statement about a state or condition of the enterprise to be brought about or sustained through appropriate Means. An EnterpriseGoal amplifies an EnterpriseVision that is, it indicates what must be satisfied on a continuing basis to effectively attain the EnterpriseVision.

Class.name: EnterprisePhase
Class.notes: A current or future state of the wholeLifeEnterprise or another EnterprisePhase.

Class.name: EnterpriseVision
Class.notes: A Vision describes the future state of the enterprise, without regard to how it is to be achieved.

Class.name: Environment
Class.notes: A definition of the environmental factors in which something exists or functions. The definition of an Environment element can be further defined using EnvironmentKind.

Class.name: EnvironmentProperty
Class.notes: A property of an Environment that is typed by a Condition.  The kinds of Condition that can be represented are Location, GeoPoliticalExtentType and Environment.

Class.name: Finding
Class.notes: An ascertainment made in the model, which relates to the methodology used, the subject under consideration, the tool or something else.

Class.name: FitCriterion
Class.notes: This element represents an acceptance criterion for a functional or non-functional requirement.

Class.name: FulfilmentCriterion
Class.notes: This element represents a criterion for evaluating the degree of implementation of a functional or non-functional requirement.

Class.name: HighLevelOperationalConcept
Class.notes: Describes the Resources and Locations required to meet an operational scenario from an integrated systems point of view. It is used to communicate overall quantitative and qualitative system characteristics to stakeholders

Class.name: InformationElement
Class.notes: An item of information that flows between OperationalPerformers and is produced and consumed by the OperationalActivities that the OperationalPerformers are capable to perform (see IsCapableToPerform).

Class.name: KnownResource
Class.notes: Asserts that a known ResourcePerformer constrains the implementation of the OperationalPerformer that plays the role in the LogicalArchitecture.

Class.name: Location
Class.notes: A specification of the generic area in which a LocationHolder is required to be located.

Class.name: MeasurementType
Class.notes: A type of a property representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

Class.name: NaturalResource
Class.notes: Type of physical resource that occurs in nature.

Class.name: OperationalAgent
Class.notes: An abstract type grouping Operational Architecture and Operational Performer.

Class.name: OperationalArchitecture
Class.notes: A type used to denote a model of the Architecture, described from the Operational perspective.

Class.name: OperationalAsset
Class.notes: An abstract element used to group the elements of OperationalAgent and InformationElement allowing them to own InformationRoles.

Class.name: OperationalConstraint
Class.notes: A Rule governing a logical architectural element i.e. OperationalPerformer, OperationalActivity, InformationElement etc.

Class.name: OperationalInterface
Class.notes: A declaration that specifies a contract between the OperationalPerformer it is related to, and any other OperationalPerformers it can interact with.

Class.name: OperationalPerformer
Class.notes: A logical entity that IsCapableToPerform OperationalActivities which produce, consume and process Resources.

Class.name: OperationalStateDescription
Class.notes: A state machine describing the behavior of a OperationalPerformer, depicting how the OperationalPerformer responds to various events and the actions.

Class.name: Organization
Class.notes: A group of OrganizationalResources (Persons, Posts, Organizations and Responsibilities) associated for a particular purpose.

Class.name: OrganizationalResource
Class.notes: An abstract type for Organization, Person Post and Responsibility.

Class.name: PaperForm
Class.notes: Form is a digitized or digitizable document, for example a scanned document.

Class.name: Person
Class.notes: A type of a human being used to define the characteristics that need to be described for ActualPersons (e.g. properties such as address, telephone number, nationality, etc).

Class.name: PhysicalResource
Class.notes: An abstract type defining physical resources (i.e. OrganizationalResource, ResourceArtifact and NaturalResource).

Class.name: Post
Class.notes: A type of job title or position that a person can fill (e.g. Lawyer, Solution Architect, Machine Operator or Chief Executive Officer).

Class.name: Project
Class.notes: A type that describes types of time-limited endeavours that are required to meet one or more Capability needs.

Class.name: ProjectMilestone
Class.notes: A type of event in a Project by which progress is measured.

Class.name: Protocol
Class.notes: A Standard for communication over a network. Protocols may be composite, represented as a ProtocolStack made up of ProtocolLayers.

Class.name: Protocolstack
Class.notes: A sub type of Protocol that contains the ProtocolLayers, defining a complete stack.

Class.name: Recommendation
Class.notes: Need for action from a finding.

Class.name: Reference
Class.notes: Element describes all types of references.

Class.name: RequirementCatalogue
Class.notes: Element represents a catalog of requirements, which consists of different categories (RequirementCategory) of functional and non-functional requirements.

Class.name: RequirementCategory
Class.notes: Element represents a category of a catalog of requirements.

Class.name: ResourceArchitecture
Class.notes: A type used to denote a model of the Architecture, described from the ResourcePerformer perspective.

Class.name: ResourceArtifact
Class.notes: A type of man-made object that contains no human beings (i.e. satellite, radio, petrol, gasoline, etc.).

Class.name: ResourceAsset
Class.notes: An abstract element used to group the elements of ResourcePerformer and DataElement allowing them to own DataRoles

Class.name: ResourceConstraint
Class.notes: A rule governing the structural or functional aspects of an implementation.

Class.name: ResourceInterface
Class.notes: A declaration that specifies a contract between the ResourcePerformers it is related to and any other ResourcePerformers it can interact with. It is also intended to be an implementation of a specification of an Interface in the Business and/or Service layer.

Class.name: ResourceMitigation
Class.notes: A set of measures intended to implement an OperationalMitigation. Comprises a subset of activities that are performed in mitigation of the risk to protect the asset that is the subject of risk (ResourceRole) at the physical level. In the case of a Risk applicable to security, the form of activity is a SecurityControl or an EnhancedSecurityControl, otherwise it is a Function.

Class.name: ResourcePerformer
Class.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a SecurityConstraint (there are currently no security viewpoints in the NAF).

Class.name: Responsibility
Class.notes: The type of duty required of a Person or Organization.

Class.name: SecurityEnclave
Class.notes: Collection of information systems connected by one or more internal networks under the control of a single authority and security policy. The systems may be structured by physical proximity or by function, independent of location.  Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

Class.name: ServiceInterface
Class.notes: A contract that defines the ServiceMethods and ServiceMessageHandlers that the ServiceSpecification realizes.

Class.name: ServicePolicy
Class.notes: A constraint governing the use of one or more ServiceSpecifications.

Class.name: ServiceSpecification
Class.notes: The specification of a set of functionality provided one element for the use of others.

Class.name: SMEReference
Class.notes: Element stands for a result of a workshop or expert knowledge.

Class.name: Software
Class.notes: A sub-type of ResourceArtifact that specifies an executable computer program.

Class.name: Standard
Class.notes: A ratified and peer-reviewed specification that is used to guide or constrain the architecture. A Standard may be applied to any element in the architecture.

Class.name: StrategicConstraint
Class.notes: A Rule governing a capability.

Class.name: SubjectOfForecast
Class.notes: An abstract type grouping elements that can be the subject of a Forecast.

Class.name: System
Class.notes: An integrated set of elements, subsystems, or assemblies that accomplish a defined objective. These elements include products (hardware, software, firmware), processes, people, information, techniques, facilities, services, and other support elements (INCOSE SE Handbook V4, 2015).

Class.name: Technology
Class.notes: A sub type of ResourceArtifact that indicates a technology domain, i.e. nuclear, mechanical, electronic, mobile telephony etc.

Class.name: View
Class.notes: An architecture view expresses the architecture of the system-of-interest in accordance with an architecture viewpoint (or simply, viewpoint). [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

Class.name: Viewpoint
Class.notes: An architecture viewpoint frames (to formulate or construct in a particular style or language) one or more concerns. A concern can be framed by more than one viewpoint.  [ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011(E)].

Class.name: WholeLifeConfiguration
Class.notes: A set of VersionedElements.

Class.name: WholeLifeEnterprise
Class.notes: A WholeLifeEnterprise is a purposeful endeavor of any size involving people, organizations and supporting systems. It is made up of TemporalParts and StructuralParts.

Part.name: AssetRole
Part.notes: AssetRole as applied to Security views, an abstract element that indicates the type of elements  that can be considered as a subject for security analysis in the particular context (currently no security viewpoints in the framework).

Part.name: CapabilityRole
Part.notes: A high level specification of the enterprise's ability to execute a specified course of action.

Part.name: ConceptRole
Part.notes: Usage of a ConceptItem in the context of a HighLevelOperationalConcept.

Part.name: DataRole
Part.notes: A usage of DataElement that exists in the context of an ResourceAsset. It also allows the representation of the whole-part aggregation of DataElements.

Part.name: InformationRole
Part.notes: A usage of InformationElement that exists in the context of an OperationalAsset. It also allows the representation of the whole-part aggregation of InformationElements.

Part.name: Measurement
Part.notes: A property of an element representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

Part.name: OperationalRole
Part.notes: Usage of a OperationalPerformer or OperationalArchitecture in the context of another OperationalPerformer or OperationalArchitecture. Creates a whole-part relationship.

Part.name: OperationalSignalProperty
Part.notes: A property of an OperationalSignal typed by OperationalExchangeItem. It enables OperationalExchangeItem e.g. InformationElement to be passed as arguments of the OperationalSignal.

Part.name: PostRole
Part.notes: A usage of a post in the context of another OrganizationalResource. Creates a whole-part relationship.

Part.name: ProblemDomain
Part.notes: A property associated with a logical architecture, used to specify the scope of the problem.

Part.name: ProjectMilestoneRole
Part.notes: The role played by a ProjectMilestone in the context of a Project.

Part.name: ProjectRole
Part.notes: Usage of a Project in the context of another Project. Creates a whole-part relationship.

Part.name: ProjectTheme
Part.notes: A property of a ProjectMilestone that captures an aspect by which the progress of ActualProjects may be measured.

Part.name: ProtocolLayer
Part.notes: Usage of a Protocol in the context of another Protocol. Creates a whole-part relationship.

Part.name: ResourceRole
Part.notes: Usage of a ResourcePerformer in the context of another ResourcePerformer. Creates a whole-part relationship.

Part.name: ResourceSignalProperty
Part.notes: A property of an ResourceSignal typed by ResourceExchangeItem. It enables ResourceExchangeItem e.g. DataElement to be passed as arguments of the ResourceSignal.

Part.name: ServiceSpecificationRole
Part.notes: An assertion that a ServiceSecification calls upon another ServiceSpecification in order to deliver its stated functionality.

Part.name: SubOrganization
Part.notes: A type of a human being used to define the characteristics that need to be described for ActualPersons (e.g. properties such as address, telephone number, nationality, etc).

Part.name: TemporalPart
Part.notes: A current or future state of the wholeLifeEnterprise or another EnterprisePhase.

Part.name: VersionOfConfiguration
Part.notes: A property of a WholeLifeConfiguration, used in version control of a VersionedElement. It asserts that a VersionedElement is a version of a WholeLifeConfiguration.

Activity.name: BusinessProcess
Activity.notes: An abstract type that represents a behavior or process (i.e. a Function or OperationalActivity) that can be performed by a Performer.

Activity.name: Function
Activity.notes: An Activity which is specified in the context to the ResourcePerformer (human or machine) that IsCapableToPerform it.

Activity.name: OperationalActivity
Activity.notes: An Activity that captures a logical process, specified independently of how the process is carried out.

Activity.name: SecurityProcess
Activity.notes: The security-related procedure that satisfies the security control requirement. Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

Activity.name: ServiceFunction
Activity.notes: An Activity that describes the abstract behavior of ServiceSpecifications, regardless of the actual implementation.

Activity.name: StandardOperationalActivity
Activity.notes: A sub-type of OperationalActivity that is a standard operating procedure.

Requirement.name: FunctionalRequirement
Requirement.notes: The element represents a functional requirement (what should the system / software be able to do?).

Requirement.name: NonfunctionalRequirement
Requirement.notes: The element represents a non-functional requirement (how should the system / software be able to do something?).

Abstraction.name: CapabilityForTask
Abstraction.notes: A tuple that asserts that a Capability is required in order for an Enterprise to conduct a phase of an EnduringTask.

Abstraction.name: Consumes
Abstraction.notes: A tuple that asserts that a service in someway contributes or assists in the execution of an OperationalActivity.

Abstraction.name: Exhibits
Abstraction.notes: A tuple that exists between a CapableElement and a Capability that it meets under specific environmental conditions.

Abstraction.name: Implements
Abstraction.notes: A tuple that defines how an element in the upper layer of abstraction is implemented by a semantically equivalent element (i.e. tracing the OperationalActivities to the Functions that implement them) in the lower level of abstraction.

Abstraction.name: IsCapableToPerform
Abstraction.notes: A relationship that says that a capable element performs an activity or action.

Abstraction.name: MapsToCapability
Abstraction.notes: A tuple denoting that an Activity contributes to providing a Capability.

Abstraction.name: OwnsProcess
Abstraction.notes: A dependency relationship denoting that an ActualOrganizationResource owns an OperationalActivity.

Abstraction.name: PerformsInContext
Abstraction.notes: A relationship that says that a role performs an activity or action. It indicates that the action can be carried out by the role when used in a specific context or configuration.

Abstraction.name: RequiresCompetence
Abstraction.notes: A tuple that asserts that an ActualOrganizationalResource is required to have a specific set of Competencies.

Abstraction.name: ServiceProvision
Abstraction.notes: An assertion that a Resource delivers a Service to a specified ServiceLevel.

Generalization.name: CapabilityGeneralization
Generalization.notes: A CapabilityGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general Capability and a more specific Capability.

Generalization.name: ProcessGeneralization
Generalization.notes: A ProcessGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general Process and a more specific Process.

Generalization.name: PropertySetGeneralisation
Generalization.notes: A PropertySetGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general PropertySet and a more specific PropertySet.

Generalization.name: ServiceSpecificationGeneralization
Generalization.notes: A ServiceSpecificationGeneralization is a taxonomic relationship between a more general ServiceSpecification and a more specific ServiceSpecification.

DataType.name: Condition
DataType.notes: A type that defines the Location, Environment and/or GeoPoliticalExtent.

DataType.name: GeoPoliticalExtentType
DataType.notes: A geospatial extent whose boundaries are defined by declaration or agreement by political parties.

DataType.name: Location
DataType.notes: A specification of the generic area in which a LocationHolder is required to be located.

Action.name: FunctionAction
Action.notes: A call of a Function indicating that the Function is performed by a ResourceRole in a specific context.

Action.name: OperationalActivityAction
Action.notes: A call of an OperationalActivity in the context of another OperationalActivity.

Action.name: ServiceFunctionAction
Action.notes: A call of a ServiceFunction in the context of another ServiceFunction.

ControlFlow.name: FunctionControlFlow
ControlFlow.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of control between FunctionActions.

ControlFlow.name: OperationalControlFlow
ControlFlow.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of control between OperationalActivityActions.

ControlFlow.name: OperationalMessageFlow
ControlFlow.notes: A ProcessMessageFlow that shows the flow of message between OperationalActivityActions of different ActivityPartitions like Pools.

ObjectFlow.name: FunctionObjectFlow
ObjectFlow.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of Resources (objects/data) between FunctionActions.

ObjectFlow.name: OperationalObjectFlow
ObjectFlow.notes: An ActivityEdge that shows the flow of Resources (objects/information) between OperationalActivityActions.

Message.name: InteractionMessage
Message.notes: An abstract type that groups several types of messages used in the InteractionScenario.

Message.name: OperationalMessage
Message.notes: Message for use in an Operational Event-Trace which carries any of the subtypes of OperationalExchange.

Message.name: ResourceMessage
Message.notes: Message for use in an Resource Event-Trace which carries any of the subtypes of ResourceExchange.

Message.name: ServiceMessage
Message.notes: Message for use in a Service Event-Trace.

Lifeline.name: InteractionRole
Lifeline.notes: An abstract type that represents an individual participant in the InteractionScenario.

Connector.name: OperationalConnector
Connector.notes: A Connector that goes between OperationalRoles representing a need to exchange Resources. It can carry a number of OperationalExchanges.

Connector.name: ResourceConnector
Connector.notes: A channel for exchange between two ResourceRoles.

Connector.name: ServiceConnector
Connector.notes: A channel for exchange between two ServiceSpecifications. Where one acts as the consumer of the other.

Operation.name: OperationalMethod
Operation.notes: behavioral feature of a OperationalPerformer whose behavior is specified in an OperationalActivity.

Operation.name: ResourceMethod
Operation.notes: A behavioral feature of a ResourcePerformer whose behavior is specified in a Function.

Operation.name: ServiceMethod
Operation.notes: A behavioral feature of a ServiceSpecification whose behavior is specified in a ServiceFunction.

Parameter.name: OperationalParameter
Parameter.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of an OperationalActivity. It is typed by an OperationalExchangeItem.

Parameter.name: ResourceParameter
Parameter.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of an Function. It is typed by a ResourceInteractionItem.

Parameter.name: ServiceParameter
Parameter.notes: A type that represents inputs and outputs of a ServiceFunction, represents inputs and outputs of a ServiceSpecification.

Port.name: OperationalPort
Port.notes: An interaction point for an OperationalAgent through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by an OperationalInterface.

Port.name: ResourcePort
Port.notes: An interaction point for a ResourcePerformer through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by a ResourceInterface.

Port.name: ServicePort
Port.notes: An interaction point for a ServiceSpecification through which it can interact with the outside environment and which is defined by a ServiceInterface.

Signal.name: OperationalSignal
Signal.notes: An item of information that flows between OperationalPerformers and is produced and consumed by the OperationalActivities that the OperationalPerformers are capable of performing (see IsCapableToPerform).

Signal.name: ResourceSignal
Signal.notes: A property of an element representing something in the physical world, expressed in amounts of a unit of measure.

Aggregation.name: PartOfCatalogue
Aggregation.notes: This relation states that a category (RequirementCategory) belongs to a requirements catalog (RequirementCatalogue).

Aggregation.name: PartOfCategory
Aggregation.notes: This relation states that his functional or non-functional requirement belongs to a category (RequirementCategory) of the requirements catalog.

StateMachine.name: ResourceStateDescription
StateMachine.notes: A state machine describing the behavior of a ResourcePerformer, depicting how the ResourcePerformer responds to various events and the actions.

StateMachine.name: ServiceStateDescription
StateMachine.notes: A state machine descripting the behavior of a ServiceSpecification, depicting how the ServiceSpecification responds to various events and the actions.

StateMachine.name: StateDescription
StateMachine.notes: An abstract type that represents a state machine (i.e. an OperationalStateDescription or ResourceStateDescription), depicting how the Asset responds to various events and the actions.

Constraint.name: Rule
Constraint.notes: An abstract type for all types of constraint (i.e. an OperationalConstraint could detail the rules of accountancy best practice).

Constraint.name: SecurityConstraint
Constraint.notes: A type of rule that captures a formal statement to define security laws, regulations, guidances, and policy. Element is not used in the current version of the framework and reserved for future developments.

Diagram_Custom.name: A1 - Meta-Data Definitions
Diagram_Custom.notes: Architectures, particularly large ones, usually require meta-data tags to aid with searching and discovery.

Diagram_Custom.name: A2 - Architecture Products
Diagram_Custom.notes: The A2 Viewpoint specifies the structure of an architecture, and the products that describe the architecture. Each product may correspond to an architecture view. This viewpoint also traces the architectures onto the Enterprise Phases they correspond to (see also C2  Enterprise Vision) and identifies the key stakeholders, their concerns and the products that address those concerns (from ISO/IEC/IEEE Standards).

Diagram_Custom.name: A3 - Architecture Correspondence
Diagram_Custom.notes: ISO/IEC/IEEE42010 introduces the idea of architecture correspondence and correspondence rules. Quoting from ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010; A correspondence defines a relation between AD (Architecture Description) elements. Correspondences are used to express architecture relations of interest within an architecture description (or between architecture descriptions). Correspondences can be governed by correspondence rules. Correspondence rules are used to enforce relations within an architecture description (or between architecture descriptions).

Diagram_Custom.name: A4 - Methodology Used
Diagram_Custom.notes: The A4 Viewpoint specifies the methodology used for the architecting activities. This methodology is described in NAFv4 Chapter 2. The content of the A4 viewpoint can also be modeled in the A1 viewpoint.

Diagram_Custom.name: A5 - Architecture Status
Diagram_Custom.notes: Since NAFv3.0, it has been possible to assign version numbers to views and specify their approval dates. In NAFv4.0, this is integrated with the meta-models generic project and milestone approach so that architecture releases are tracked against the architecture delivery project. The content of the A5 viewpoint can also be modeled in the A1 viewpoint.

Diagram_Custom.name: A6 - Architecture Version
Diagram_Custom.notes: Where the A5 Viewpoint shows the current version number and approval status for the architecture, the A6 Viewpoint shows the complete history of the architecture.

Diagram_Custom.name: A7 - Architecture Compliance
Diagram_Custom.notes: The A7 Viewpoint gives the overall specification of architecture meta-data.

Diagram_Custom.name: A8 - Standards
Diagram_Custom.notes: The A8 Viewpoint encompasses both technical and non-technical standards. The standards specified in the A8 view can be applied across the architecture to a variety of structural and behavioural elements. Standards are essential to the coherent running of businesses and to the delivery of reliable, interoperable systems.

Diagram_Custom.name: Ar - Architecture Roadmap
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Ar Viewpoint shows the history of the architecture project as well as its future direction.

Diagram_Custom.name: C1 - Capability Taxonomy
Diagram_Custom.notes: The C1 Viewpoint specifies all the capabilities that are referenced throughout one or more architectures  i.e. one C1 may provide the definitive list of capabilities for a number of logical and resource architectures. The capabilities may be organised into specialisation hierarchies (taxonomies). Measures of Effectiveness (MoE) may be specified for each capability. Note that MoEs are inherited down a capability taxonomy.

Diagram_Custom.name: C2 - Enterprise Vision
Diagram_Custom.notes: The purpose of the C2 Viewpoint is to provide a strategic context for the capabilities described in the architecture and to specify the scope for the architecture. The C2 Viewpoint is high-level and describes the vision, goals, enduring tasks and capabilities using terminology that is easily understood by non-technical readers.

Diagram_Custom.name: C3 - Capability Dependencies
Diagram_Custom.notes: The C3 Viewpoint is intended to provide a means of analysing the dependencies between capabilities and between capability clusters. The composition of capabilities (into clusters) is logical and the purpose of the clusters is to guide enterprise management.

Diagram_Custom.name: C4 - Standard Processes
Diagram_Custom.notes: The C4 Viewpoint specifies Standard Operational Activities that can be re-used across multiple logical architectures (e.g. in L4, Logical Activities).

Diagram_Custom.name: C5 - Effects
Diagram_Custom.notes: The purpose of the C5 Viewpoint is to describe the operational effect of the capabilities, activities and services according to the expected goals. The C5 Viewpoint is high-level description that should be easily understood by non-technical readers.

Diagram_Custom.name: C7 - Performance Parameters
Diagram_Custom.notes: In the C7 Viewpoint the capability requirements (and existing capabilities) can be expressed in terms of Measures of Effectiveness (MoEs). These are high-level metrics used to judge the level of capability.

Diagram_Custom.name: C8 - Planning Assumptions
Diagram_Custom.notes: The C8 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of assumptions that have been made for the implementation of capabilities. Assumptions can be expressed by means of requirements.

Diagram_Custom.name: Cr - Capability Roadmap
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Cr Viewpont supports the Capability Audit process by providing a method to identify gaps or duplications in capability provision. Cr indicates capability increments, which are derived from delivery milestones within acquisition projects.

Diagram_Custom.name: L1 - Node Types
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L1 Viewpoint defines all of the Nodes that will appear in a Logical Architecture. Nodes are elements of capability assembled and orchestrated in the Logical Architecture (see L2 - Logical Scenario and L4 - Logical Activities views). The levels of capability provided by each node are expressed as Measures of Performance (MoPs) and these may be dependent on the environments in which the Node is required to operate.

Diagram_Custom.name: L2 - Logical Scenario
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L2 Viewpoint specifies Nodes (elements of capability) in context of each other. The context is usually expressed in terms of the information that flows between the nodes (e.g. the information flow requirements between capabilities in a given scenario) but may also be flows of materiel, human resource or energy.

Diagram_Custom.name: L3 - Node Interactions
Diagram_Custom.notes: L3 is used to provide further detail of the interoperability requirements associated with the operational capability of interest. The focus is on logical flows that cross the capability boundary. Although the primary purpose of the L3 Viewpoint is to specify information exchanges, the L3 may also list flows of materiel, energy and human resources.

Diagram_Custom.name: L4 - Logical Activities
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L4 Viewpoint describes the operational activities that are being conducted within the mission or scenario. These activities are defined at a logical, solution-neutral level so as to enable different solutions in the physical layer. The L4 Viewpoint describes the activities associated with the logical architecture, as well as the:

Diagram_Custom.name: L5 - Logical States
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L5 Viewpoint specifies the typical states a node may have and the possible transitions between those states (i.e. changes of state). Triggers for state changes may also be defined. Actions may be associated with a given state or with the transition between states in response to stimuli (e.g. triggers and events).

Diagram_Custom.name: L7 - Information Model
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L7 Viewpoint is used to document the business information. It describes the information that can be exchanged along the logical flows in the architecture, specified in L3 Node Interactions.

Diagram_Custom.name: L8 - Logical Constraints
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L8 Viewpoint is used to constrain the logical architecture without forcing a particular solution. L8 is used for rules which are not expressed as behavioural models, interactions or measures of effectiveness, i.e. they are textual statements of requirements that constrain the architecture.

Diagram_Custom.name: Lr - Lines of Development
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Lr Viewpoint is primarily intended to support the acquisition process across multiple projects or programmes, highlighting dependencies the logical dependencies between capabilities, projects and the integration of all lines of development to achieve a successfully integrated military capability. Use of the Lr Viewpoint should support the management of capability delivery and be aligned with Cr, Capability Roadmap.

Diagram_Custom.name: L2-L3 - Logical Concept
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L2-L3 Viewpoint is concerned with providing an executive level, scenario-based communication of the architecture purpose, scope and content.

Diagram_Custom.name: P1 - Resource Types
Diagram_Custom.notes: The P1 Viewpoint collects together all the Resource Types in the architecture together with a depiction of their performance characteristics. P1 also provides a summary of the technologies and competencies that impact on the Resources that constitute the architecture.

Diagram_Custom.name: P2 - Resource Structure
Diagram_Custom.notes: The P2 Viewpoint links together the operational and physical architecture viewpoints by depicting how types of Resource are structured and interact to realize the logical architecture specified in L2, Logical Scenario. The P2 Viewpoint may represent the realization of a requirement specified in a L2 (i.e. in a to-be architecture) and so there may be many alternative Resource viewpoint suites that could realize the operational requirement. Alternatively, in an as-is architecture, a L2 may just be a simplified, logical representation of the P2 Viewpoint to allow communication of key information flows to non-technical stakeholders.

Diagram_Custom.name: P3 - Resource Connectivity
Diagram_Custom.notes: The networks and pathways documented in a P3 Viewpoint represent the physical implementation of the logical flows identified in a L2, Logical Scenario, or L3, Node Interactions View.

Diagram_Custom.name: P4 - Resource Functions
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Functionality Description provides detailed information regarding the allocation of functions to resources, and flows between Resource Functions. The P4 Viewpoint is the Physical Resource counterpart to the L4 Logical Activities Viewpoint.

Diagram_Custom.name: P5 - Resource States
Diagram_Custom.notes: The P5 Viewpoint identifies the states a Resource can be, the allowable changes between those states, and the stimuli (e.g. triggers and events) that cause the state changes.

Diagram_Custom.name: P7 -  Data Model
Diagram_Custom.notes: The P7 Viewpoint is one of the architectural products closest to actual system design in the NAF. It is used to describe how the information represented in the L7 Logical Data Model Viewpoint is implemented.

Diagram_Custom.name: P8 - Resource Constraints
Diagram_Custom.notes: The P8 Viewpoint describes constraints on the Resources, Resource Functions, data and communications that make up a Physical Architecture.

Diagram_Custom.name: Pr - Configuration Management
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Pr Viewpoint provides an overview of how Resource Assets change over time (note that NAF v3.1 only allowed for Capability Configurations whereas now this is opened up to all Resource Types). It shows the structure of different versions of Resource Assets (usually Capability Configurations or Service Implementations) mapped against a timeline.

Diagram_Custom.name: L4-P4 - Activity To Function Mapping
Diagram_Custom.notes: The L4-P4 Viewpoint depicts the mapping of Resource Functions (and optionally, the resources that provide them) to operational activities and/or service functions. For operational activities it thus identifies the transformation of an operational need into a purposeful action performed by a system or solution. For service functions it provides the link between the services used at the operational level and the specific Resource Functions provided by the resources supporting the services.

Diagram_Custom.name: S1 - Service Taxonomy
Diagram_Custom.notes: The purpose of the S1 Viewpoint is to provide a governance structure for a Service-Oriented Architecture. Along with S3, Service Interfaces, it specifies a standard library of service specifications for an enterprise, to which service implementers are expected to conform.

Diagram_Custom.name: S2 - Service Structure
Diagram_Custom.notes: The S2 Viewpoint is concerned with identification and description of how services are structured to create a higher-aggregated service. To provide highlevel views, dependencies to other services, nodes and resources as well as service interfaces and service functions can be represented.

Diagram_Custom.name: S3 - Service Interfaces
Diagram_Custom.notes: The S3 Viewpoint is concerned with the identification and definition of service interfaces.

Diagram_Custom.name: S4 - Service Functions
Diagram_Custom.notes: The S4 Viewpoint is the key behavioural specification for services. Equivalent in nature to L4, Logical Activities and P4, Resources Functions, it specifies a set of functions that a service implementation is expected to perform. Implementation of that behaviour is represented in P4, Resource Functions, and L4-P4, Activity to Function Mapping.

Diagram_Custom.name: S5 - Service States
Diagram_Custom.notes: The S5 Viewpoint is a specification of the allowable states of a service, and the possible transitions between them. This specification constrains how implementations of the service will behave.  It is, though, generally considered a good practice to make services stateless - i.e. consumers of a service are not aware of what state the service is in.

Diagram_Custom.name: S7 - Service Interface Parameters
Diagram_Custom.notes: Specifies the interfaces that a service provides and uses, defines which services are compatible with which other services.

Diagram_Custom.name: S8 - Service Policy
Diagram_Custom.notes: The S8 Viewpoint specifies constraints against services to which implementations must conform.

Diagram_Custom.name: Sr - Service Roadmap
Diagram_Custom.notes: The Sr Viewpoint supports the Service Audit process by providing a method to identify gaps or duplications in service provision. Sr indicates service lifetime evolutions, which are derived from delivery milestones within acquisition projects.

Diagram_Custom.name: C1-S1 - Capability to Service Mapping
Diagram_Custom.notes: A C1-S1 Viewpoint presents a simple mapping of services to capabilities, showing which services contribute to which capability.

Diagram_Custom.name: R2 - Requirement Catalogue
Diagram_Custom.notes: The R2 represents a catalog of requirements in the architectural model. For this purpose, categories can be created in which the functional and non-functional requirements can be grouped.

Diagram_Custom.name: R3 - Requirement Dependencies
Diagram_Custom.notes: The R3 is used to show dependencies between different requirements.

Diagram_Custom.name: R7 - Requirement Derivation
Diagram_Custom.notes: The R7 assigns functional and non-functional requirements to the demanding architectural elements. In addition, information about the planned realization can be shown.

Diagram_Custom.name: R8 - Requirement Fulfilment
Diagram_Custom.notes: The R8 is used to determine and map acceptance and evaluation criteria for the individual functional and non-functional requirements.

Diagram_Custom.name: Rr - Requirement Realization
Diagram_Custom.notes: In the Rr, requirements are assigned to the realizing architectural elements.

Diagram_Sequence.name: L6 - Logical Sequence
Diagram_Sequence.notes: Operational Event-Trace Descriptions, sometimes called sequence diagrams, event scenarios or timing diagrams, allow the tracing of interactions between nodes in a scenario or critical sequence of events. The node interactions usually correspond to flows of information but may describe flows of energy, materiel or people specified in the L2, Logical Scenario.

Diagram_Sequence.name: P6 - Resource Sequence
Diagram_Sequence.notes: The P6 Viewpoint is valuable for moving to the next level of detail from the initial solution design, to help define a sequence of functions and Resource Interactions, and to ensure that each participating Resource or Port has the necessary information, at the right time, in order to perform its assigned functionality.

Diagram_Sequence.name: S6 - Service Interactions
Diagram_Sequence.notes: Service Interaction Descriptions, sometimes called sequence diagrams, event scenarios or timing diagrams, allow the tracing of interactions between services in a composition or critical sequence of events.
